docs.lead_paragraph: As criticism of soaring prescription drug prices in the U.S. grows, global spending on medicines is expected to rise 3 percent to 6 percent annually for the next five years, according to a new forecast from IMS Health.

headline.main: IMS Health: Drug Spending to Jump 30 Pct. To $1.3T in 2020
headline.print_headline: IMS Health: Drug Spending to Jump 30 Pct. To $1.3T in 2020

docs.snippet: As criticism of soaring prescription drug prices in the U.S. grows, global spending on medicines is expected to rise 3 percent to 6 percent annually for the next five years, according to a new forecast from IMS Health.

headline.main: In Bangladesh, a Half-Century of Saving Lives With  Data

docs.abstract: A research center in rural Bangladesh that formulated and tested oral rehydration solution to stop childhood diarrhea in the 1960s has saved millions of lives since by continuing to monitor public health.
docs.snippet: A research center in rural Bangladesh that formulated and tested oral rehydration solution to stop childhood diarrhea in the 1960s has saved millions of lives since by continuing to monitor public health.

docs.lead_paragraph: When a 2-year-old returned sick from a visit to India, U.S. doctors suspected tuberculosis even though standard tests said no. It would take three months to confirm she had an extreme form of the disease — a saga that highlights the desperate need for better ways to fight TB in youngsters in countries that can't afford such creative care.

headline.main: Rare TB Case Shows Diagnosing, Treating Children Is Tough
headline.print_headline: Rare TB Case Shows Diagnosing, Treating Children Is Tough
